steps.description: Modify the app service in docker-compose.yml to add a volume mount for hot-reload development. Add the volume mount './ProgressPath:/src:cached' under the volumes section of the app service. This mounts the source directory into the container at /src (matching the WORKDIR in the SDK stage) for live code updates.

Add a 'command' override to the app service in docker-compose.yml that runs 'dotnet watch run --project /src/ProgressPath.csproj' instead of the production entrypoint. This enables hot-reload during development. The command should use the SDK image instead of the runtime image.

Change the app service 'build' configuration in docker-compose.yml to use a different approach for development: Add a 'target: build' to stop at the SDK stage (build stage) instead of continuing to runtime, since hot-reload requires the SDK. The build context should be '.' (root) and the dockerfile path should be 'ProgressPath/Dockerfile'.

Update the Dockerfile to add a named development stage that uses the SDK image and is configured for hot-reload. Add a new stage called 'development' after the build stage that: 1) Uses 'FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0 AS development', 2) Sets WORKDIR to /src, 3) Installs Node.js for Tailwind CSS watching, 4) Exposes port 5000, 5) Sets ASPNETCORE_URLS to http://+:5000, 6) Sets ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT to Development. The docker-compose will target this stage.

Update docker-compose.yml to target the 'development' stage in the Dockerfile. Change the build section to include 'target: development'. Update the port mapping to '5000:5000' since the development stage uses port 5000. Update the command to 'dotnet watch run --no-hot-reload' (using file watching instead of hot-reload which can have issues in Docker) or keep 'dotnet watch run' for full hot-reload support.

Update the .env.example file to add alternative variable name comments clarifying the naming convention. Add comments next to each variable explaining that the double-underscore format (e.g., LLM__Provider) maps to the .NET configuration hierarchy (LLM:Provider). Optionally add the exact variable names from the specification as aliases (e.g., 'LLM_PROVIDER=openai' as an alternative) with a note that both formats work.

considerations: The hot-reload setup requires using the SDK image (not runtime) because dotnet watch needs the SDK tools to rebuild on file changes
Volume mounting the source code means the Dockerfile's COPY steps are effectively bypassed during development - the mounted volume takes precedence
For hot-reload in Docker, dotnet watch run is the correct approach but may require enabling polling for file changes (DOTNET_USE_POLLING_FILE_WATCHER=1) on some systems
The development stage in Dockerfile should not include the npm install/build steps since those are done via the volume mount where node_modules already exists on the host
Port 5000 should be used consistently for development (the production Dockerfile uses port 80, but development convention is 5000)
The .NET double-underscore convention (LLM__Provider) is required for environment variable configuration binding in ASP.NET Core - this maps to LLM:Provider in the configuration hierarchy
Consider adding DOTNET_WATCH_RESTART_ON_RUDE_EDIT=true to allow watch to handle changes that require full restart
The Tailwind CSS build for hot-reload may need npm run watch:css running in parallel or the css needs to be pre-built - consider adding this to the development workflow documentation
